habitat_description:
The House Sparrow (Passer domesticus) is always associated with humans and never found in a habitat unaltered by human activity.   It is found in a wide variety of areas such as cities, suburbs, farms (Kaufman 1996), and woodland edges near human habitation, especially around horses (Ehrlich et al. 1988).  It is absent from extensive woodlands, forests, grasslands, deserts (Peter and Cink 2006).

It is a permanent resident of the Sandia Mountains of New Mexico below 2073 m in the Sandia Mountains (Tatschl 1967).  It is a common, permanent resident in cities, towns, and ranches in Utah (Behle et al. 1985).  Is a widespread common resident in cities and towns in Arizona (Monson and Phillips 1981).  Leadville and Fairplay, Colorado, host the highest elevation populations of this species in North America at 3110m and 3048 m, respectively (Kingery 1998).   It occurs in all counties in Texas.  

The House Sparrow prefers to nest in a cavity such as a natural cavity in a tree, an abandoned woodpecker hole, a birdhouse, a hole in a wall, under the eaves of a building, behind a wall-mounted sign, or in the nest of a Cliff or Barn Swallow (Nicholson 1997).  It can be an aggressive competitor with native species for cavities, sometimes ejecting eggs or young.  If a cavity is not available, it will build a nest in the fork of a tree branch up to 40 feet above the ground.  It forages primarily on the ground (Ehrlich et al. 1988) but is an opportunistic feeder and will frequent bird feeders and pick insects from the grill of cars (Kaufman 1996).  N. Tarr, 3May2013.
